Beginner here.  

 

I totally agree.  The things I seem to need the most guidance in are

-          writing code that is easily test-able with plain old junit
(and not cactus, since most everyone seems to frown on that)

-          and writing tests for existing code that wasn't written with
unit testing in mind.

 

Getting us to "think in junit" sums it up about right.  That's the holy
grail.

 

Good luck with getting this off the ground.

Brenda

________________________________

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Simon Chappell
Sent: Friday, November 24, 2006 8:52 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Essay: The Trouble With JUnit

 

I'd like some thoughts from the list on a little something that I've
written. The essay is called "The Trouble With JUnit" and can be found
at the following URL.

http://simonpeter.org/technology/writings/thetroublewithjunit.html
<http://simonpeter.org/technology/writings/thetroublewithjunit.html> 

My question to the list is: am I over-reacting or is there a need for
more material for the beginners?

Simon

-- 
simonpeter.org | simonpeter.com | techbook.info
